awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Models for Early Paleozoic Deposition, Volcanism, and Biotas of Sibumasu: Implications for Tectonics and Paleogeography
awd_abstract_narration:
The time period between 505 to 485 million years ago was a dynamic time in Earth's history and included extensive volcanic activity and the evolution of ancient organisms that then occupied the world's shallow oceans. Unfortunately, there are few places in the world that  have the volcanic ash beds that are needed to really understand the timing of events during this period. However, there is one region where the record of ancient volcanoes and their ashes has survived: an ancient fragment of Asia called "Sibumasu", which comprises parts of Thailand, Malaysia, Myanmar, and southwestern China. In Sibumasu, ashes and sedimentary rocks with fossils are layered in many thick sections, offering the opportunity to obtain high precision dates from the ashes, and insight into the feedbacks between the physical and biological worlds during this transformative time in Earth history. In addition, this project will incorporate the training of graduate and undergraduate students across three U.S. institutions and will partner with a complementary UNESCO funded IGCP668 project on Sibumasu that supports the participation of scientists from developing countries to attend meetings and workshops in Thailand, Myanmar, China, Japan, and the USA. 

This project will determine the age of the rocks found in the Sibumasu region in order to understand the pattern of Earth-Life interactions.  To do this, the team will incorporate a multidisciplinary approach to the project including extensive field sampling, paleogeographic analyses of fossils, geochemical rock characterization, and a variety of geochronologic techniques. Further, the team will work in partnership with the Myanmar Geosciences Society to produce an illustrated children's book in Burmese featuring the fossils of Mt. Hsingmango, and what they say about regional Earth history. The story also will be modified for use with the National Institute of Design's chitrakatha workshop for India's nationally ranked graphic art students and will form the basis of an animated story of India's migration across the Tethys Ocean and collision with Asia that will have broad educational reach across the subcontinent.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project tests three hypotheses concerning early Paleozoic deposition, volcanism, and biotas of the Sibumasu microcontinent. These are: (1) that latest Cambrian strata and associated volcanic rocks in Myanmar and Thailand record the late Cambrian Kurgiakh orogeny; (2) that the late Paleozoic and Mesozoic Sibumasu terrane may not have had a long-lived, unified paleogeographic and tectonic history prior to the opening of the Tethyan Ocean; and (3) that integration of geochronologic and paleontological data from Sibumasu will yield a means of global correlation and allow for a major advance in the calibration of the upper Cambrian geochronologic time scale.

            In order to address the three hypotheses listed above we first needed to establish the late Cambrian geochronologic and paleontological framework for Sibumasu. This was done through field campaigns on Ko Tarutau, Thailand, and in the Southern Shan State, Myanmar. These allowed for extensive collection of trilobites and other invertebrates, ash bed samples for geochronology, and sandstone samples for detrital zircon age analyses, all of which were collected in precise stratigraphic context.  Combined systematic paleontological descriptions and high-precision U-Pb geochronology from these sections has established a late Cambrian age for both of the deposits between ca. 492 and 484 million years ago. Important findings include the first description of Cambrian trilobites from Myanmar, that a faunal link exists between Thailand and Myanmar as part of Sibumasu, and between Sibumasu and Australia. These associations fit within a broader context of Gondwanan reconstructions, including correlations with Northern China. Additional detrital zircon data show similar provenance for sediment in Thailand and Myanmar and are currently being compared to provenance data for Tibet, Baoshan, and Vietnam in order to better establish the paleogeography of the time.

            The high-precision U-Pb zircon geochronology from sections in Thailand and Myanmar permits refinement of the late Cambrian timescale, but it remains to be established whether these designations and subdivisions based on trilobite biostratigraphy are global in nature.  If so, these data may permit a revision of the accepted age for the Cambrian-Ordovician boundary.  If not, they will point to a need to revisit the definition of that boundary in an effort to establish a globally unique time marker that can be subjected to additional high-precision geochronology.  Such attempts will lead to a better understanding of biodiversification events that led up to the well documents great Ordovician biodiversification event.

            This work has thus far resulted in numerous publications focused primarily on the paleontological findings and paleogeographic implications.  The detrital zircon and ashbed U-Pb geochronology are currently being prepared for publication.  Other significant outputs from this grant include enhanced collaborations between American, Thai, Burmese, and Chinese geologists; aid in establishing a Satun UNESCO Global Geopark in southern Thailand; work with the Thai Bureau of Mineral Resources to develop their scientific collections management policy; organization of meetings and workshops in coordination with several related IGCP Projects; the development of a children’s book titled “The Ocean at the Top of Our Mountain” about the geological history of Myanmar, to be published in Palaung, Burmese, and English and distributed within Myanmar in collaboration with the Myanmar Geosciences Society; and production of an animated version of the book, now available on Youtube, in collaboration with Indian designers.
